Write a poem about Nature:
She has no need to fear the fall
Of harvest from the laddered reach
Of orchards, nor the tide gone ebbing
      From the steep beach.

Nor hold to pain's effrontery
Her body's bulwark, stern and savage,
Nor be a glass, where to forsee
      Another's ravage.

What she has gathered, and what lost,
She will not find to lose again.
She is possessed by time, who once
      Was loved by men.

Write a poem about Nature:
I
The winter evening settles down
With smell of steaks in passageways.
Six oclock.
The burnt-out ends of smoky days.
And now a gusty shower wraps
The grimy scraps
Of withered leaves about your feet
And newspapers from vacant lots;
The showers beat
On broken blinds and chimney-pots,
And at the corner of the street
A lonely cab-horse steams and stamps.

And then the lighting of the lamps.

II
The morning comes to consciousness
Of faint stale smells of beer
From the sawdust-trampled street
With all its muddy feet that press
To early coffee-stands.
With the other masquerades
That time resumes,
One thinks of all the hands
That are raising dingy shades
In a thousand furnished rooms.

III
You tossed a blanket from the bed,
You lay upon your back, and waited;
You dozed, and watched the night revealing
The thousand sordid images
Of which your soul was constituted;
They flickered against the ceiling.
And when all the world came back
And the light crept up between the shutters
And you heard the sparrows in the gutters,
You had such a vision of the street
As the street hardly understands;
Sitting along the beds edge, where
You curled the papers from your hair,
Or clasped the yellow soles of feet
In the palms of both soiled hands.

IV
His soul stretched tight across the skies
That fade behind a city block,
Or trampled by insistent feet
At four and five and six oclock;
And short square fingers stuffing pipes,
And evening newspapers, and eyes
Assured of certain certainties,
The conscience of a blackened street
Impatient to assume the world.

I am moved by fancies that are curled
Around these images, and cling:
The notion of some infinitely gentle
Infinitely suffering thing.

Wipe your hand across your mouth, and laugh;
The worlds revolve like ancient women
Gathering fuel in vacant lots.

Write a poem about Nature:
The willows carried a slow sound,
A sarabande the wind mowed on the mead.
I could never remember
That seething, steady leveling of the marshes
Till age had brought me to the sea.

Flags, weeds. And remembrance of steep alcoves
Where cypresses shared the noons
Tyranny; they drew me into hades almost.
And mammoth turtles climbing sulphur dreams
Yielded, while sun-silt rippled them
Asunder ...

How much I would have bartered! the black gorge
And all the singular nestings in the hills
Where beavers learn stitch and tooth.
The pond I entered once and quickly fled
I remember now its singing willow rim.

And finally, in that memory all things nurse;
After the city that I finally passed
With scalding unguents spread and smoking darts
The monsoon cut across the delta
At gulf gates ... There, beyond the dykes

I heard wind flaking sapphire, like this summer,
And willows could not hold more steady sound.

Write a poem about Nature:
Twelve o'clock.
Along the reaches of the street
Held in a lunar synthesis,
Whispering lunar incantations
Dissolve the floors of memory
And all its clear relations,
Its divisions and precisions,
Every street lamp that I pass
Beats like a fatalistic drum,
And through the spaces of the dark
Midnight shakes the memory
As a madman shakes a dead geranium.

Half-past one,
The street lamp sputtered,
The street lamp muttered,
The street lamp said, "Regard that woman
Who hesitates towards you in the light of the door
Which opens on her like a grin.
You see the border of her dress
Is torn and stained with sand,
And you see the corner of her eye
Twists like a crooked pin."

The memory throws up high and dry
A crowd of twisted things;
A twisted branch upon the beach
Eaten smooth, and polished
As if the world gave up
The secret of its skeleton,
Stiff and white.
A broken spring in a factory yard,
Rust that clings to the form that the strength has left
Hard and curled and ready to snap.

Half-past two,
The street lamp said,
"Remark the cat which flattens itself in the gutter,
Slips out its tongue
And devours a morsel of rancid butter."
So the hand of a child, automatic,
Slipped out and pocketed a toy that was running along the quay.
I could see nothing behind that child's eye.
I have seen eyes in the street
Trying to peer through lighted shutters,
And a crab one afternoon in a pool,
An old crab with barnacles on his back,
Gripped the end of a stick which I held him.

Half-past three,
The lamp sputtered,
The lamp muttered in the dark.

The lamp hummed:
"Regard the moon,
La lune ne garde aucune rancune,
She winks a feeble eye,
She smiles into corners.
She smoothes the hair of the grass.
The moon has lost her memory.
A washed-out smallpox cracks her face,
Her hand twists a paper rose,
That smells of dust and old Cologne,
She is alone
With all the old nocturnal smells
That cross and cross across her brain."
The reminiscence comes
Of sunless dry geraniums
And dust in crevices,
Smells of chestnuts in the streets,
And female smells in shuttered rooms,
And cigarettes in corridors
And cocktail smells in bars."

The lamp said,
"Four o'clock,
Here is the number on the door.
Memory!
You have the key,
The little lamp spreads a ring on the stair,
Mount.
The bed is open; the tooth-brush hangs on the wall,
Put your shoes at the door, sleep, prepare for life."

The last twist of the knife.

Archibald MacLeish, The Rock in the Sea from Collected Poems 1917-1982. Copyright  1985 by The Estate of Archibald MacLeish. Reprinted with the permission of Houghton Mifflin Company. All rights reserved.

Write a poem about Nature:
Out of the winds' and the waves' riot,
Out of the loud foam,
He has put in to a great quiet
And a still home.

Here he may lie at ease and wonder
Why the old ship waits,
And hark for the surge and the strong thunder
Of the full Straits,

And look for the fishing fleet at morning,
Shadows like lost souls,
Slide through the fog where the seal's warning
Betrays the shoals,

And watch for the deep-sea liner climbing
Out of the bright West,
With a salmon-sky and her wake shining
Like a tern's breast, 

And never know he is done for ever
With the old sea's pride,
Borne from the fight and the full endeavour
On an ebb tide.

Write a poem about Nature:
Maurice, weep not, I am not here under this pine tree.
The balmy air of spring whispers through the sweet grass,
The stars sparkle, the whippoorwill calls,
But thou grievest, while my soul lies rapturous
In the blest Nirvana of eternal light!
Go to the good heart that is my husband,
Who broods upon what he calls our guilty love: i
Tell him that my love for you, no less than my love for him
Wrought out my destiny i that through the flesh
I won spirit, and through spirit, peace.
There is no marriage in heaven,
But there is love.

Write a poem about Nature:
Hugh MacDiarmid, The Sauchs in the Reuch Heuch Hauch from Selected Poetry. Copyright  1992 by Alan Riach and Michael Grieve. Reprinted with the permission of New Directions Publishing Corporation.

Write a poem about Nature:
The earth builds on the earth
Castles and towers;
The earth saith of the earth:
All shall be ours.

Yea, though they plan and reap
The rye and the corn,
Lo, they were bond to Sleep
Ere they were born.

Yea, though the blind earth sows
For the fruit and the sheaf,
They shall harvest the leaf of the rose
And the dust of the leaf.

Pride of the sword and power
Are theirs at their need
Who shall rule but the root of the flower
The fall of the seed.

They who follow the flesh
In splendour and tears,
They shall rest and clothe them afresh
In the fulness of years.

From the dream of the dust they came
As the dawn set free.
They shall pass as the flower of the flame
Or the foam of the sea.

The earth builds on the earth
Castles and towers.
The earth saith of the earth:
All shall be ours.

Write a poem about Nature:
May I for my own self song's truth reckon,
Journey's jargon, how I in harsh days
Hardship endured oft.
Bitter breast-cares have I abided,
Known on my keel many a care's hold,
And dire sea-surge, and there I oft spent
Narrow nightwatch nigh the ship's head
While she tossed close to cliffs. Coldly afflicted,
My feet were by frost benumbed.
Chill its chains are; chafing sighs
Hew my heart round and hunger begot
Mere-weary mood. Lest man know not
That he on dry land loveliest liveth,
List how I, care-wretched, on ice-cold sea,
Weathered the winter, wretched outcast
Deprived of my kinsmen;
Hung with hard ice-flakes, where hail-scur flew,
There I heard naught save the harsh sea
And ice-cold wave, at whiles the swan cries,
Did for my games the gannet's clamour,
Sea-fowls, loudness was for me laughter,
The mews' singing all my mead-drink.
Storms, on the stone-cliffs beaten, fell on the stern
In icy feathers; full oft the eagle screamed
With spray on his pinion.
Not any protector
May make merry man faring needy.
This he little believes, who aye in winsome life
Abides 'mid burghers some heavy business,
Wealthy and wine-flushed, how I weary oft
Must bide above brine.
Neareth nightshade, snoweth from north,
Frost froze the land, hail fell on earth then
Corn of the coldest. Nathless there knocketh now
The heart's thought that I on high streams
The salt-wavy tumult traverse alone.
Moaneth alway my mind's lust
That I fare forth, that I afar hence
Seek out a foreign fastness.
For this there's no mood-lofty man over earth's midst,
Not though he be given his good, but will have in his youth greed;
Nor his deed to the daring, nor his king to the faithful
But shall have his sorrow for sea-fare
Whatever his lord will.
He hath not heart for harping, nor in ring-having
Nor winsomeness to wife, nor world's delight
Nor any whit else save the wave's slash,
Yet longing comes upon him to fare forth on the water.
Bosque taketh blossom, cometh beauty of berries,
Fields to fairness, land fares brisker,
All this admonisheth man eager of mood,
The heart turns to travel so that he then thinks
On flood-ways to be far departing.
Cuckoo calleth with gloomy crying,
He singeth summerward, bodeth sorrow,
The bitter heart's blood. Burgher knows not 
He the prosperous man  what some perform
Where wandering them widest draweth.
So that but now my heart burst from my breast-lock,
My mood 'mid the mere-flood,
Over the whale's acre, would wander wide.
On earth's shelter cometh oft to me,
Eager and ready, the crying lone-flyer,
Whets for the whale-path the heart irresistibly,
O'er tracks of ocean; seeing that anyhow
My lord deems to me this dead life
On loan and on land, I believe not
That any earth-weal eternal standeth
Save there be somewhat calamitous
That, ere a man's tide go, turn it to twain.
Disease or oldness or sword-hate
Beats out the breath from doom-gripped body.
And for this, every earl whatever, for those speaking after 
Laud of the living, boasteth some last word,
That he will work ere he pass onward,
Frame on the fair earth 'gainst foes his malice,
Daring ado, ...
So that all men shall honour him after
And his laud beyond them remain 'mid the English,
Aye, for ever, a lasting life's-blast,
Delight mid the doughty.
Days little durable,
And all arrogance of earthen riches,
There come now no kings nor Csars
Nor gold-giving lords like those gone.
Howe'er in mirth most magnified,
Whoe'er lived in life most lordliest,
Drear all this excellence, delights undurable!
Waneth the watch, but the world holdeth.
Tomb hideth trouble. The blade is layed low.
Earthly glory ageth and seareth.
No man at all going the earth's gait,
But age fares against him, his face paleth,
Grey-haired he groaneth, knows gone companions,
Lordly men are to earth o'ergiven,
Nor may he then the flesh-cover, whose life ceaseth,
Nor eat the sweet nor feel the sorry,
Nor stir hand nor think in mid heart,
And though he strew the grave with gold,
His born brothers, their buried bodies
Be an unlikely treasure hoard.

Write a poem about Nature:
Out in the sky the great dark clouds are massing;
I look far out into the pregnant night,
Where I can hear a solemn booming gun
And catch the gleaming of a random light,
That tells me that the ship I seek is passing, passing.

My tearful eyes my soul's deep hurt are glassing;
For I would hail and check that ship of ships.
I stretch my hands imploring, cry aloud,
My voice falls dead a foot from mine own lips,
And but its ghost doth reach that vessel, passing, passing.

O Earth, O Sky, O Ocean, both surpassing,
O heart of mine, O soul that dreads the dark!
Is there no hope for me? Is there no way
That I may sight and check that speeding bark
Which out of sight and sound is passing, passing?

Write a poem about Nature:
Air a-gittin' cool an' coolah,
   Frost a-comin' in de night,
Hicka' nuts an' wa'nuts fallin',
   Possum keepin' out o' sight.
Tu'key struttin' in de ba'nya'd,
   Nary step so proud ez his;
Keep on struttin', Mistah Tu'key,
   Yo' do' know whut time it is.

Cidah press commence a-squeakin'
   Eatin' apples sto'ed away,
Chillun swa'min' 'roun' lak ho'nets,
   Huntin' aigs ermung de hay.
Mistah Tu'key keep on gobblin'
   At de geese a-flyin' souf,
Oomph! dat bird do' know whut's comin';
   Ef he did he'd shet his mouf.

Pumpkin gittin' good an' yallah
   Mek me open up my eyes;
Seems lak it's a-lookin' at me
   Jes' a-la'in' dah sayin' "Pies."
Tu'key gobbler gwine 'roun' blowin',
   Gwine 'roun' gibbin' sass an' slack;
Keep on talkin', Mistah Tu'key,
   You ain't seed no almanac.

Fa'mer walkin' th'oo de ba'nya'd
   Seein' how things is comin' on,
Sees ef all de fowls is fatt'nin'
   Good times comin' sho's you bo'n.
Hyeahs dat tu'key gobbler braggin',
   Den his face break in a smile
Nebbah min', you sassy rascal,
   He's gwine nab you atter while.

Choppin' suet in de kitchen,
   Stonin' raisins in de hall,
Beef a-cookin' fu' de mince meat,
   Spices groun'I smell 'em all.
Look hyeah, Tu'key, stop dat gobblin',
   You ain' luned de sense ob feah,
You ol' fool, yo' naik's in dangah,
   Do' you know Thanksgibbin's hyeah?

Write a poem about Nature:
Wintah, summah, snow er shine,
Hit's all de same to me,
Ef only I kin call you mine,
An' keep you by my knee.

Ha'dship, frolic, grief er caih,
Content by night an' day,
Ef only I kin see you whaih
You wait beside de way.

Livin', dyin', smiles er teahs,
My soul will still be free,
Ef only thoo de comin' yeahs
You walk de worl' wid me.

Bird-song, breeze-wail, chune er moan,
What puny t'ings dey'll be,
Ef w'en I's seemin' all erlone,
I knows yo' hea't's wid me.

Write a poem about Nature:
The brawling of a sparrow in the eaves,   
The brilliant moon and all the milky sky,   
And all that famous harmony of leaves,   
Had blotted out man's image and his cry.

A girl arose that had red mournful lips
And seemed the greatness of the world in tears,   
Doomed like Odysseus and the labouring ships   
And proud as Priam murdered with his peers;

Arose, and on the instant clamorous eaves,   
A climbing moon upon an empty sky,   
And all that lamentation of the leaves,   
Could but compose man's image and his cry.

Write a poem about Nature:
Now in the West the slender moon lies low,
And now Orion glimmers through the trees,
Clearing the earth with even pace and slow,
And now the stately-moving Pleiades,
In that soft infinite darkness overhead
Hang jewel-wise upon a silver thread.

And all the lonelier stars that have their place,
Calm lamps within the distant southern sky,
And planet-dust upon the edge of space,
Look down upon the fretful world, and I
Look up to outer vastness unafraid
And see the stars which sang when earth was made.

Write a poem about Nature:
I spot the hills
With yellow balls in autumn.
I light the prairie cornfields
Orange and tawny gold clusters
And I am called pumpkins.
On the last of October
When dusk is fallen
Children join hands
And circle round me
Singing ghost songs
And love to the harvest moon;
I am a jack-o'-lantern
With terrible teeth
And the children know
I am fooling.

Write a poem about Nature:
Green miles of leafy peace are spread
Over these ranks, unseen and serried;
Screening the trenches with their dead
And living men already buried.
The rains beat down, the torrents flow
Into each cold and huddling cave;
And over them the beet-fields grow,
A fortress gentle as a grave.

Morose, impatient, sick at heart,
With rasping nerves and twitching muscles,
We cannot even sleep; we start
With every twig that snaps or rustles.
Sought always by an unseen foe
Over our heads the bullets fly;
But more than these, we fear the snow,
The silent shrapnel of the sky.

Yonder our colonel stalks and grieves,
Meeting the storm with thoughts more stormy;
But we, we sit and watch the leaves
Fall down, a torn and crumpled army.
We mourn for every leaf that lies,
As though it were a comrade slain;
Each was a shelter from the eyes
Of every prying aeroplane. . . 

And in its cloudy uniform,
Stilling the cannons earthly thunder,
The huge artillery of the storm
Plows through the land and pulls it under.
The rain beats down, until the slow
And slipping earth resists no more. . .
And over them the beets will grow
Ranker and redder than before.

Hugh MacDiarmid, The Watergaw from Selected Poetry. Copyright  1992 by Alan Riach and Michael Grieve. Reprinted with the permission of New Directions Publishing Corporation.

Write a poem about Nature:
[Version 1: 1921]
The quick sparks on the gorse bushes are leaping,
Little jets of sunlight-texture imitating flame;
Above them, exultant, the peewits are sweeping:
They are lords of the desolate wastes of sadness their screamings proclaim.

Rabbits, handfuls of brown earth, lie
Low-rounded on the mournful grass they have bitten down to the quick.
Are they asleep?  Are they alive?  Now see, when I
Move my arms the hill bursts and heaves under their spurting kick.

The common flaunts bravely; but below, from the rushes
Crowds of glittering king-cups surge to challenge the blossoming bushes;
There the lazy streamlet pushes
Its curious course mildly; here it wakes again, leaps, laughs, and gushes.

Into a deep pond, an old sheep-dip,
Dark, overgrown with willows, cool, with the brook ebbing through so slow,
Naked on the steep, soft lip
Of the bank I stand watching my own white shadow quivering to and fro.

What if the gorse flowers shrivelled and kissing were lost?
Without the pulsing waters, where were the marigolds and the songs of the brook!
If my veins and my breasts with love embossed
Withered, my insolent soul would be gone like flowers that the hot wind took.

So my soul like a passionate woman turns,
Filled with remorseful terror to the man she scorned, and her love
For myself in my own eyes' laughter burns,
Runs ecstatic over the pliant folds rippling down to my belly from the breast-lights above.

Over my sunlit skin the warm, clinging air,
Rich with the songs of seven larks singing at once, goes kissing me glad.
And the soul of the wind and my blood compare
Their wandering happiness, and the wind, wasted in liberty, drifts on and is sad.

Oh but the water loves me and folds me,
Plays with me, sways me, lifts me and sinks me as though it were living blood,
Blood of a heaving woman who holds me,
Owning my supple body a rare glad thing, supremely good.

[Version 2: 1928]
The quick sparks on the gorse-bushes are leaping
Little jets of sunlight texture imitating flame;
Above them, exultant, the peewits are sweeping:
They have triumphed again o'er the ages, their screamings proclaim.

Rabbits, handfuls of brown earth, lie
Low-rounded on the mournful turf they have bitten down to the quick.
Are they asleep?  are they living?  Now see, when I
Lift my arms, the hill bursts and heaves under their spurting kick!

The common flaunts bravely; but below, from the rushes
Crowds of glittering king-cups surge to challenge the blossoming bushes;
There the lazy streamlet pushes
His bent course mildly; here wakes again, leaps, laughs, and gushes

Into a deep pond, an old sheep-dip,
Dark, overgrown with willows, cool, with the brook ebbing through so slow;
Naked on the steep, soft lip
Of the turf I stand watching my own white shadow quivering to and fro.

What if the gorse-flowers shrivelled, and I were gone?
What if the waters ceased, where were the marigolds then, and the gudgeon?
What is this thing that I look down upon?
White on the water wimples my shadow, strains like a dog on a string, to run on.

How it looks back, like a white dog to its master!
I on the bank all substance, my shadow all shadow looking up to me, looking back!
And the water runs, and runs faster, runs faster,
And the white dog dances and quivers, I am holding his cord quite slack.

But how splendid it is to be substance, here!
My shadow is neither here nor there; but I, I am royally here!
I am here! I am here! screams the peewit; the may-blobs burst out in a laugh as they hear!
Here! flick the rabbits. Here! pants the gorse. Here! say the insects far and near.

Over my skin in the sunshine, the warm, clinging air
Flushed with the songs of seven larks singing at once, goes kissing me glad.
You are here! You are here! We have found you! Everywhere
We sought you substantial, you touchstone of caresses, you naked lad!

Oh but the water loves me and folds me,
Plays with me, sways me, lifts me and sinks me, murmurs: Oh marvellous stuff!
No longer shadow!  and it holds me
Close, and it rolls me, enfolds me, touches me, as if never it could touch me enough.

Sun, but in substance, yellow water-blobs!
Wings and feathers on the crying, mysterious ages, peewits wheeling!
All that is right, all that is good; all that is God takes substance! a rabbit lobs
In confirmation, I hear sevenfold lark-songs pealing.

Write a poem about Nature:
The trees are in their autumn beauty,
The woodland paths are dry,
Under the October twilight the water
Mirrors a still sky;
Upon the brimming water among the stones
Are nine-and-fifty swans.

The nineteenth autumn has come upon me
Since I first made my count;
I saw, before I had well finished,
All suddenly mount
And scatter wheeling in great broken rings
Upon their clamorous wings.

I have looked upon those brilliant creatures,
And now my heart is sore.
All's changed since I, hearing at twilight,
The first time on this shore,
The bell-beat of their wings above my head,
Trod with a lighter tread.

Unwearied still, lover by lover,
They paddle in the cold
Companionable streams or climb the air;
Their hearts have not grown old;
Passion or conquest, wander where they will,
Attend upon them still.

But now they drift on the still water,
Mysterious, beautiful;
Among what rushes will they build,
By what lake's edge or pool
Delight men's eyes when I awake some day
To find they have flown away?

Write a poem about Nature:
Give me hunger,
O you gods that sit and give
The world its orders.
Give me hunger, pain and want,
Shut me out with shame and failure
From your doors of gold and fame,
Give me your shabbiest, weariest hunger!

But leave me a little love,
A voice to speak to me in the day end,
A hand to touch me in the dark room
Breaking the long loneliness.
In the dusk of day-shapes
Blurring the sunset,
One little wandering, western star
Thrust out from the changing shores of shadow.
Let me go to the window,
Watch there the day-shapes of dusk
And wait and know the coming
Of a little love.

Write a poem about Nature:
Passing through huddled and ugly walls,
By doorways where women haggard
Looked from their hunger-deep eyes,
Haunted with shadows of hunger-hands,
Out from the huddled and ugly walls,
I came sudden, at the city's edge,
On a blue burst of lake,
Long lake waves breaking under the sun
On a spray-flung curve of shore;
And a fluttering storm of gulls,
Masses of great gray wings
And flying white bellies
Veering and wheeling free in the open.

Write a poem about Nature:
Desolate and lone
All night long on the lake
Where fog trails and mist creeps,
The whistle of a boat
Calls and cries unendingly,
Like some lost child
In tears and trouble
Hunting the harbor's breast
And the harbor's eyes.

Write a poem about Nature:
Momus is the name men give your face,
The brag of its tone, like a long low steamboat whistle
Finding a way mid mist on a shoreland,
Where gray rocks let the salt water shatter spray Against horizons purple, silent.

Yes, Momus,
Men have flung your face in bronze
To gaze in gargoyle downward on a street-whirl of folk.
They were artists did this, shaped your sad mouth,
Gave you a tall forehead slanted with calm, broad wisdom;
All your lips to the corners and your cheeks to the high bones
Thrown over and through with a smile that forever wishes and wishes, purple, silent, fled from all the iron things of life, evaded like a sought bandit, gone into dreams, by God.

I wonder, Momus,
Whether shadows of the dead sit somewhere and look with deep laughter
On men who play in terrible earnest the old, known, solemn repetitions of history.
A droning monotone soft as sea laughter hovers from your kindliness of bronze,
You give me the human ease of a mountain peak, purple, silent;
Granite shoulders heaving above the earth curves,
Careless eye-witness of the spawning tides of men and women
Swarming always in a drift of millions to the dust of toil, the salt of tears,
And blood drops of undiminishing war.

Write a poem about Nature:
I shall foot it
Down the roadway in the dusk,
Where shapes of hunger wander
And the fugitives of pain go by.

I shall foot it
In the silence of the morning,
See the night slur into dawn,
Hear the slow great winds arise
Where tall trees flank the way
And shoulder toward the sky.

The broken boulders by the road
Shall not commemorate my ruin.
Regret shall be the gravel under foot.
I shall watch for
Slim birds swift of wing
That go where wind and ranks of thunder
Drive the wild processionals of rain.

The dust of the travelled road
Shall touch my hands and face.

Write a poem about Nature:
I have sat here happy in the gardens,
Watching the still pool and the reeds
And the dark clouds
Which the wind of the upper air
Tore like the green leafy boughs
Of the divers-hued trees of late summer;
But though I greatly delight
In these and the water-lilies,
That which sets me nighest to weeping
Is the rose and white color of the smooth flag-stones,
And the pale yellow grasses
Among them.

Write a poem about Nature:
Potuia, potuia
White grave goddess,
Pity my sadness,
O silence of Paros.

I am not of these about thy feet,
These garments and decorum;
I am thy brother,
Thy lover of aforetime crying to thee,
And thou hearest me not.

I have whispered thee in thy solitudes
Of our loves in Phrygia,
The far ecstasy of burning noons
When the fragile pipes
Ceased in the cypress shade,
And the brown fingers of the shepherd
Moved over slim shoulders;
And only the cicada sang.

I have told thee of the hills
And the lisp of reeds
And the sun upon thy breasts,

And thou hearest me not,
Potuia, potuia
Thou hearest me not.

Write a poem about Nature:
The ancient songs
Pass deathward mournfully.

Cold lips that sing no more, and withered wreaths,
Regretful eyes, and drooping breasts and wings
Symbols of ancient songs
Mournfully passing
Down to the great white surges,
Watched of none         - -
Save the frail sea-birds
And the lithe pale girls,
Daughters of Okeanos.

And the songs pass
From the green land
Which lies upon the waves as a leaf
On the flowers of hyacinth;
And they pass from the waters,
The manifold winds and the dim moon,
And they come,
Silently winging through soft Kimmerian dusk,
To the quiet level lands
That she keeps for us all,
That she wrought for us all for sleep
In the silver days of the earth's dawning
Proserpine, daughter of Zeus.

And we turn from the Kuprian's breasts,
And we turn from thee,
Phoibos Apollon,
And we turn from the music of old
And the hills that we loved and the meads,
And we turn from the fiery day,
And the lips that were over-sweet;
For silently
Brushing the fields with red-shod feet,
With purple robe
Searing the flowers as with a sudden flame,
Death,
Thou hast come upon us.

And of all the ancient songs
Passing to the swallow-blue halls
By the dark streams of Persephone,
This only remains:
That in the end we turn to thee,
Death,
That we turn to thee, singing
One last song.

O Death,
Thou art an healing wind
That blowest over white flowers
A-tremble with dew;
Thou art a wind flowing
Over long leagues of lonely sea;
Thou art the dusk and the fragrance;
Thou art the lips of love mournfully smiling;
Thou art the pale peace of one
Satiate with old desires;
Thou art the silence of beauty,
And we look no more for the morning;
We yearn no more for the sun,
Since with thy white hands,
Death,
Thou crownest us with the pallid chaplets,
The slim colorless poppies
Which in thy garden alone
Softly thou gatherest.

And silently;
And with slow feet approaching;
And with bowed head and unlit eyes,
We kneel before thee:
And thou, leaning towards us, Caressingly layest upon us
Flowers from thy thin cold hands,
And, smiling as a chaste woman Knowing love in her heart,
Thou sealest our eyes
And the illimitable quietude
Comes gently upon us.

Write a poem about Love:
Knowlt Hoheimer ran away to the war
The day before Curl Trenary
Swore out a warrant through Justice Arnett
For stealing hogs.
But that's not the reason he turned a soldier.
He caught me running with Lucius Atherton.
We quarreled and I told him never again
To cross my path.
Then he stole the hogs and went to the war
Back of every soldier is a woman.

Write a poem about Love:
He protested all his life long
The newspapers lied about him villainously;
That he was not at fault for Minerva's fall,
But only tried to help her.
Poor soul so sunk in sin he could not see
That even trying to help her, as he called it,
He had broken the law human and divine.
Passers by, an ancient admonition to you:
If your ways would be ways of pleasantness,
And all your pathways peace,
Love God and keep his commandments.

Write a poem about Love:
W. B. Yeats, The Circus Animals Desertion from The Poems of W. B. Yeats: A New Edition, edited by Richard J. Finneran. Copyright 1933 by Macmillan Publishing Company, renewed  1961 by Georgie Yeats. Reprinted with the permission of A. P. Watt, Ltd. on behalf of Michael Yeats.

Write a poem about Love:
Were you but lying cold and dead,
And lights were paling out of the West,
You would come hither, and bend your head,
And I would lay my head on your breast;
And you would murmur tender words,
Forgiving me, because you were dead:
Nor would you rise and hasten away,
Though you have the will of wild birds,
But know your hair was bound and wound
About the stars and moon and sun:
O would, beloved, that you lay
Under the dock-leaves in the ground,
While lights were paling one by one.

Write a poem about Love:
Never give all the heart, for love
Will hardly seem worth thinking of
To passionate women if it seem
Certain, and they never dream
That it fades out from kiss to kiss;
For everything thats lovely is
But a brief, dreamy, kind delight.
O never give the heart outright,
For they, for all smooth lips can say,
Have given their hearts up to the play.
And who could play it well enough
If deaf and dumb and blind with love?
He that made this knows all the cost,
For he gave all his heart and lost.

Write a poem about Love:
Why should I blame her that she filled my days
With misery, or that she would of late
Have taught to ignorant men most violent ways,
Or hurled the little streets upon the great,
Had they but courage equal to desire?
What could have made her peaceful with a mind
That nobleness made simple as a fire,
With beauty like a tightened bow, a kind
That is not natural in an age like this,
Being high and solitary and most stern?
Why, what could she have done, being what she is?
Was there another Troy for her to burn?

Write a poem about Love:
Some may have blamed you that you took away
The verses that could move them on the day
When, the ears being deafened, the sight of the eyes blind
With lightning, you went from me, and I could find
Nothing to make a song about but kings,
Helmets, and swords, and half-forgotten things
That were like memories of youbut now
We'll out, for the world lives as long ago;
And while we're in our laughing, weeping fit,
Hurl helmets, crowns, and swords into the pit.
But, dear, cling close to me; since you were gone,
My barren thoughts have chilled me to the bone.

Write a poem about Love:
Shy one, shy one,
Shy one of my heart,
She moves in the firelight
Pensively apart.

She carries in the dishes,
And lays them in a row.
To an isle in the water
With her would I go.

She carries in the candles,
And lights the curtained room,
Shy in the doorway
And shy in the gloom;

And shy as a rabbit,
Helpful and shy.
To an isle in the water
With her would I fly.

Story about a Story:
Once upon a time in the land of Policymia, there lived two leaders named Majora and Minoro. Their job was to make sure all the citizens had beautiful parks, clean water, and top-notch schools. But there were so many things to fix! How would they ever decide where to start?

Majora, being the wise leader she was, knew just what to do. She invited her fellow policymakers for a big meeting at the Roundtable of Representatives. There, they discussed the most important problems Policymia faced. This was called identifying "key policy areas." It meant figuring out which topics needed attention first.

Next came assessing support  finding out if everyone agreed on the solutions. Some people thought building more playgrounds was the way to go, while others wanted better libraries. To understand everyone's thoughts, Majora used something called 'polling.' Just like taking a vote, polling helped her see what ideas were popular among her friends (the majority) and also those across the aisle (people who didn't belong to her political group).

While talking to her friends and colleagues, Majora discovered that almost everyone loved science! And why not? Science could help create amazing inventions, protect nature, and even cure sicknesses. So, the policymakers decided to build a super cool SCIENCE CENTER right at the heart of Policymia!

But then, an unexpected problem popped up! A grumpy neighboring kingdom threatened to block Policymia's plans because they feared losing visitors to the new center. Oh no! However, instead of giving up, Majora saw this challenge as an opportunity. If they could work together with the grumpy neighbors, maybe both lands could benefit. That way, everybody wins, showing the true spirit of teamwork and collaboration in the world of policies!

Story about a Story:
In the heart of Harmonyville, nestled between two neighboring countries, lay a magnificent bridge. Not only did it connect the land masses, but it also joined hearts and minds of folks living on either side. Let's call our beloved structure 'The Friendship Bridge'.

One bright morning, Sarah from Sunnyhill and Maria from Starshine decided to explore this marvelous architectural feat. As they skipped along its vibrant pathway adorned with multicolored flags fluttering cheerily, Sarah asked, "Maria, do you know how bridges stand strong despite all the cars going over them?"

With a curious smile, Maria replied, "Well, I think it has something to do with physics! Bridges use different types of forces like tension, compression, and torsion to balance themselves out."

Sarah gasped, "Wow! That sounds complicated. But then again," she pointed towards the distant mountains, "those tall peaks must face greater force by wind and snow. Yet, they stand firm too!"

As the day wore on, they reached the middle of the bridge where an information kiosk stood proudly. There, they learned about the various parts of the bridge  abutments, piers, deck, trusses...it seemed almost alive! Each part played a crucial role just like cells in our bodies.

Just when things couldn't get any better, dark clouds rolled in unexpectedly. Rain began pouring down drenching everyone including Sarah and Maria. Their excitement turned into worry as they realized they might not make it back home before dark. Suddenly, the once familiar route appeared ominous under the stormy sky.

Despite being scared, they remembered what they had learned earlier. Just like structures need balance and harmony, so does nature. So instead of panicking, they took deep breaths calming themselves down. After all, even amidst turmoil, understanding science can bring clarity and peace. And sometimes, facing adversities hand-in-hand brings forth stronger friendships.

Story about a Story:
Little Bella loved math problems. She would spend hours every day trying to solve different kinds of equations and word problems. One sunny afternoon, she was sitting under her favorite tree when she saw a bird flying up high in the sky. She wondered how high the bird must be flying. As she looked up, she noticed something interesting about the color of the sky. It made her think of a recent math problem she had solved.

"Stream of consciousness," said Bella to herself, recalling the term used by her teacher during their language arts class. "Just like I connected those numbers in my head earlier today." Her thoughts took over again. "If the square of twenty minus thirty equals three hundred seventy, then what is the square root of three hundred seventy?" She quickly calculated in her mind and got close to nineteen.

Meanwhile, Ben, her best friend, came strolling down the street. Seeing Bella engrossed in her world of numbers, he asked curiously, "What has caught your attention so much, Bella?"

Bella shared her thought process aloud, discussing her method of solving the question about squares and differences between two consecutive integers. They continued talking until they reached another question  counting the number of poor girls among sixty percent of students being girls in Bella's classroom.

Together, they determined that a quarter of the girls were poor, meaning fifteen out of sixty were poor. After calculating the probabilities, they concluded that the chances of selecting a poor girl as a leader were slim. But then, they realized that sometimes even though things might seem unlikely or difficult, they still happenedjust like the unexpected rain shower suddenly pouring on them despite the otherwise bright weather. Even more surprising, the water seemed to wash away some chalk marks on the pavement revealing a hidden message: Sometimes, we need patience and persistence before finding answers!

Story about a Story:

Lets make our own unicorn costumes! she exclaimed. She knew that unicorns were mythical creatures with a single horn on their forehead, so she thought of ways to create one.

Next, they used ribbon to make a long, flowing mane down the back of the dress, and another one for a tail. Finally, they painted the cardboard box to look like a unicorn's magical home.

As they put on their finished costumes, they imagined what it would be like to meet a real unicorn. Suddenly, something extraordinary happened! A bright flash of light appeared before their eyes, followed by a gentle breeze. When they opened their eyes again, standing right next to them was a beautiful, majestic unicorn! It looked exactly like their costumes  pastel colors, shimmering mane, and all!

Your belief in my existence became so strong when you wore those costumes that I actually came into existence due to your collective imagination. But now, without that focus, I will slowly fade away.

Astonished, Emma asked, What can we do to help? The unicorn smiled softly. Just keep believing and sharing stories about magic and mythical creatures. That way, even though I may disappear physically, I shall continue living on in tales and dreams. And just like that, the unicorn vanished, leaving behind only memories and a powerful lesson about the power of belief, imagination, and science.

Story about a Story:
In a bustling town filled with computers and data lived two best friends, Sam and Alexa. They were always curious about how things worked and loved learning new things. One day, they discovered their friend Posty, who managed a big important database called PostGIS, was having trouble keeping up with all the updates!

"Posty," said Sam, "why do you look so tired? Is there something wrong?"

Posty sighed, "I wish I could keep our PostGIS database updated with all the latest improvements, but when I try, everything stops working!"

Alexa had an idea. "What if we could help you find a way to update without stopping the entire system? That way, everyone can still access the information they need."

Eagerly, Posty agreed, and together, they started researching ways to perform what's known as a 'rolling update.' A rolling update means making changes one part at a time, allowing other parts to continue functioning smoothly during the process.

They found out that first, they needed to install the new version of PostGIS on another computer, setting it up exactly like the current one. Then, they would add this new computer to the group of available databases that users connect to. By doing this, they could test the new system alongside the existing one to make sure everything ran perfectly before fully switching over.

Next came the trickiest part  moving some of the work from the old computer to the shiny new one. Using special tools, they carefully transferred small bits of the database until finally, one piece successfully operated on the new machine. With excitement, they checked everything over to confirm it was working flawlessly!

But then, suddenly, they faced an unexpected problem; even though most things went well, some functions weren't quite right yet. It seemed they couldn't finish the transition as easily as they thought. Despite feeling disappointed, they learned a valuable lesson that sometimes progress comes with challenges, but they mustn't give up hope. Instead, they vowed to learn more, refine their techniques, and try again, knowing that patience and persistence will lead them to success in the end.

Story about a Story:
In a bustling city filled with towering skyscrapers lived two friends named Libby and Penny who worked for different companies, ENA and P&G respectively. They were both curious about how things work and loved learning new things, especially when it came to science! One day, they found themselves facing a disagreement between their companies regarding which forum to use to solve a problem  arbitration or court.

Libby decided to take action and spoke with her company's general counsel to discuss their preferred choice. She learned many interesting facts about arbitration during their discussion. Arbitration is a way of resolving disputes outside of court by having a neutral third party make a decision based on evidence presented by each side. It can often save time and money compared to going to court. Excitedly, she shared this information with Penny.

Penny listened intently and asked questions to better understand the concept of arbitration. After some thought, she realized that while it might be faster and cheaper than court, it also meant giving up certain rights such as the right to appeal the decision. With this realization, Penny explained to Libby that although she appreciated the offer, she felt uncomfortable making a hasty decision without considering all aspects involved.

Just then, another unexpected challenge popped up! A small earthquake struck the city causing minor damage to buildings including ENA and P&G offices. This incident gave Libby and Penny an idea - what if natural disasters occurred more frequently due to climate change? Perhaps choosing arbitration would mean quicker resolution of any issues arising from these unpredictable events. However, despite its advantages, Penny still couldn't shake off her concerns about relinquishing important legal rights.

This situation taught them valuable lessons about balancing speed and cost against potential losses and risks. Although they didn't reach a conclusion immediately, their friendship deepened through open communication and mutual respect for differing opinions. Together, they looked forward to finding a solution that benefits everyone while continuing to explore scientific wonders around them.

Story about a Story:
In a bustling town full of computers and robots lived two curious kids named Alex and Taylor. They loved learning about technology and how things worked. One sunny day, they discovered some code on their friend's computer:

"Hey guys," said Charlie, "check out what I found! It's a program that creates a special address called an 'API endpoint'. When we visit this address, it sends back a friendly message."

Alex asked, "What's so cool about that?"
Taylor added, "Yeah, and what's an API anyway?"
Charlie grinned and explained, "An Application Programming Interface, or API, lets different software talk to each other. This endpoint uses something called Expressa toolkit in JavaScriptto listen for our request and then send us a response!"

They decided to create their own API endpoint together. After installing Express, they wrote:
```javascript
const express = require('express');
const app = express();

app.get('/api/our-endpoint', (req, res) => {
  res.send('Hi there, friends!');
});

app.listen(4000, () => {
  console.log('Our App listening on port 4000');
});
```
When they visited `http://localhost:4000/api/our-endpoint`, they saw the greeting proudly displayed on the screen. Their faces lit up with excitement!

As they marveled at their achievement, Taylor wondered aloud, "Why do people use numbers like '3000' and '4000' after 'listen' in these programs?"
Charlie replied, "Those numbers represent ports, which act like doorways into a computer system. Each port can handle many requests simultaneously, ensuring fast communication between devices."

Feeling accomplished, the trio continued exploring programming and APIs. However, they soon realized that creating endpoints was only part of the challenge; protecting sensitive data became another important responsibility. As they learned more about cybersecurity, they understood that sometimes even well-intentioned tools could lead to unforeseen consequences. And while they never stopped loving their coding adventures, they knew that every new discovery brought fresh responsibilities too.

Story about a Story:
In a bustling forest full of curious animals, lived Benny the bear and Daisy the deer. They loved exploring their lush home and learning new things every day. One sunny afternoon, they stumbled across something quite worrying - many of their friends had disappeared!

Benny asked Daisy, "Have you noticed that our dear friend, the majestic tiger, isn't around anymore?"
Daisy replied, concerned, "Yes, I've also missed seeing the wise old elephant lately!"

They decided to gather all their woodland friends together to discuss what might be happening. With everyone gathered under their favorite tree, Benny spoke up, "Our fellow creatures seem to vanish without a trace; any idea why?"
Fiona Fox chimed in, "Well, my family travels far and wide. Recently, we saw more humans than ever before. It seems they want to build houses near our forest."

Just then, Wally Warbler arrived fluttering his wings in distress, singing out, "It's true! My migratory path changed due to those human settlements. Many birds couldn't adapt and vanished forever."

Inspired by this revelation, Benny proposed, "We need to let people know how their actions affect us so they can help protect our home too. Let's call ourselves 'Guardians of Gaia!'"

And thus began the Guardians of Gaia's mission to educate nearby villages about preserving nature and protecting endangered species. But even after their efforts, they realized that change takes time, leaving a powerful message about patience and perseverance in conservation.

Hollywood Trail, taking around 2-3 hours to complete the 3-mile round trip.

Excitedly, they chose the Mt. Hollywood Trail and began their climb. Along the way, they discovered different plants and animals native to California. Jamie picked up a leaf and noticed its veins. She asked, "Why do these leaves have lines inside them?" Taylor replied, "Those lines help carry water and nutrients from the roots to other parts of the plant, kind of like our blood vessels!"

However, suddenly, dark clouds rolled in, and rain began pouring down. With no shelter nearby, they quickly realized they needed to head back down immediately.

As they hurried down the slippery trails, they learned firsthand why being prepared for any situation could make all the difference  especially when exploring the natural world. Despite getting soaked, they made it safely back home, grateful for both their newfound knowledge and respect for Mother Nature.

Story about a Story:
Once upon a time, in a lush green valley, there was a little girl named Molly. Molly loved animals more than anything else in the world. Her favorite were sheep, with their soft wool and gentle nature. She dreamed of working with them when she grew up.

One day, while visiting her grandpa's farm, she asked him, "Grandpa, how can I work with sheep when I grow up?" Grandpa thought for a moment and then said, "Well dear, there are many ways you can work with sheep. You could become a Sheep Farm Manager, like me."

"A Sheep Farm Manager?" Molly asked curiously. "Yes," replied Grandpa. "As a Sheep Farm Manager, you would take care of all the sheep on the farm, make sure they are healthy and happy, and help them grow beautiful wool."

Molly liked that idea, but she wanted to know more. So, Grandpa continued, "You could also become a Livestock Handler. They spend their days taking care of the sheep, making sure they have enough food and water, and keeping them safe."

Molly imagined herself running around the fields, playing with the sheep, and making sure they were okay. It sounded fun! But she still wasn't convinced if that was exactly what she wanted to do.

Then Grandpa told her about another exciting job - being a Sheep Shearer. "Sheep Shearers cut off the wool from the sheep so we can use it to make warm clothes and blankets," he explained. Molly's eyes sparkled with curiosity. She had never seen anyone shear a sheep before.

Finally, Grandpa mentioned one last job - Marketing and Sales Professional. "They find new homes for our wool products and let people know how great our sheep are!" Molly smiled, thinking about how proud she would feel showing off the amazing things made from her very own sheep's wool.

But suddenly, a loud noise interrupted their conversation. They ran outside to see what was happening and found out that a pack of wolves had invaded the farm! All the sheep were scared and didn't know what to do.

Without hesitation, Molly stepped forward. Using her newfound knowledge, she quickly organized the other workers into teams  the Sheep Farm Managers made a plan to keep the sheep safe; the Livestock Handlers herded the sheep away from danger; the Sheep Shearers used their quick hands to distract the wolves; and the Marketing and Sales Professionals called for backup from nearby farms.

Although they managed to chase the wolves away, not all the sheep survived. Even though everyone worked together and did their best, sometimes bad things happen despite our efforts. But Molly learned an important lesson that day - no matter which path she chooses, she will always be able to protect and care for the creatures she loves by combining her passion with knowledge and hard work.

While waiting out the tempest, they continued diving into the vast library of knowledge offered by the app. However, the unexpected twist came when they realized the power went out due to the intense thunderstorm. Sadly, without electricity, they couldn't use the magical educational tool any longer.

Disappointment filled their hearts momentarily until Tamara spoke up, "You know what? We learned so many cool things today because we were prepared. This experience showed us that no matter what happens or how technology fails us sometimes, our own curiosity and willingness to explore will always help us find ways to learn."

From then on, whenever faced with challenges, both Timmy and Tamara embraced the spirit of exploration and discovery. And although they missed having the convenience of the org.wikipedia app, nothing dampened their enthusiasm for seeking knowledge and understanding the wonders of the world around them.

Story about a Story:
Once upon a time in a lush green forest, there lived a curious little armadillo named Arty. Arty was always eager to learn how he could protect himself from any dangers lurking around. He asked his friend Oakley, the wise old tree, "Oakley, how do I keep myself safe from predators?"

Oakley replied, "Well, dear Arty, you have armor-like skin made up of bony plates called scutes. These help form a hard shield over your body. Whenever you feel threatened, simply curl up into a tight ball, tucking your head and legs safely inside."

One day, while exploring a new part of the forest, Arty came across a sly fox named Felix. Before Arty knew it, Felix had him cornered! But remembering Oakley's advice, Arty rolled up into a ball, protecting himself with ease. Even though Felix tried biting down on Arty's armor, all he got were sore teeth and frustration!

Feeling proud and relieved, Arty continued his journey home by digging quick burrows with his sharp claws  another great way to get away from predators. As darkness fell, Arty realized being out after sunset helped him stay safer too, since many potential threats slept during this time. With his exceptional sense of smell and hearing, he easily detected and avoided other creatures.

But one unfortunate evening, Arty discovered an unexpected truth; not all dangers come from large predators. While crossing a road under the cover of night, he didn't notice an approaching car. Swerving desperately, the driver barely missed hitting Arty. Though shaken, Arty understood then that vigilance must never waver, whether facing animal adversaries or unforeseen hazards. Life has its perils, big and smallbut learning and adapting will always light our path forward.

Story about a Story:
Little Billy loved cookies! One day, he had an idea - he wanted to figure out the average number of cookies in a package. So, he bought seven packages of his favorite kind and hurried home to count the cookies inside each one.

As he opened the first package, he saw eight delicious cookies staring back at him. Eagerly, he moved on to the second package and found ten yummy treats waiting for him! With six more packages left, Billy couldn't wait to see how many more cookies he would find.

Next up was a mysterious package labeled 'X'. Curious, Billy decided to open it and discovered that it contained fewer cookies than the others  only five! But something didn't seem right. Five wasn't even close to the amount of cookies he found in the other two packages.

"Hmm," said Billy, rubbing his chin thoughtfully. "Maybe I made a mistake. Or maybe this package has some special surprise inside!" Excitedly, he added up the total number of cookies he had counted so far: eight, ten, and now fifteen (since package X held five). There were still four more packages to go!

With every new package, Billy continued adding the cookie counts together until he reached the final tally. It turned out there were exactly 14 cookies per package on average. A little disappointed, Billy realized package X held twice the amount of cookies compared to its fellow packages. That sneaky baker! Although things hadn't gone quite as planned, Billy learned a valuable lesson about averages and counting accurately. Sometimes surprises can change the outcome!

Dr. Multiverse smiled and said that might be difficult because traveling between dimensions required more advanced technology than anyone in Quantumville possessed. Story about a Story:
In a small town named Harmonyville, there lived two curious friends, Sam and Alex. They were always eager to learn new things and explore the world around them. One sunny day, while playing near the river, they found a strange stone that looked completely blank  no colors, shapes or patterns on its surface. This intrigued both of them, and they decided to show it to their favorite teacher, Mr. Wise.

As soon as Mr. Wise saw the stone, he knew it was special. It reminded him of the ancient philosophical concept called Tabula Rasa, which means blank slate. He explained to Sam and Alex how some philosophers believe that people enter the world as blank slates, without any built-in ideas or knowledge. Instead, we gather information and develop our understanding based on experiences and observations throughout our lives.

Sam and Alex pondered over this idea as they walked home together. Suddenly, Sam had an epiphany! She said, "Alex, I think I know what Mr. Wise meant by Tabula Rasa. Our minds are like this smooth stone when we're born, right? And then all these grooves get carved into it as we grow up!"

"Wow, Sam, that's deep," replied Alex thoughtfully. "But wait...what happens if someone never has those carvings made? Like, if they don't go to school or meet different kinds of people?"

At that moment, Mr. Wise approached them with another real-life connection. "That's an excellent question, Alex. Think of your brain like a garden. If you plant seeds and take care of them, beautiful flowers bloom. But if left unattended, nothing can grow."

With excitement in their eyes, Sam and Alex thanked Mr. Wise for teaching them something so profound. However, little did they know that even though learning expands our horizons, sometimes ignorance can lead us down unexpected paths too. Their once seemingly ordinary stone turned out to be precious gemstone worth millions. Though happy initially, the kids learned that materialistic possessions aren't everything; education feeds our soul much more than wealth ever could.

Story about a Story:
In a lush, green forest, there lived tiny creatures called Fendrix and Floozit. They were best friends and loved exploring their surroundings together. One day they came across a strange plant struggling to grow.

"Why can't this plant stand tall and strong?" asked Fendrix.

Floozit replied, "Maybe it needs help from our friend, Myke the mushroom! He knows all about making things grow!"

Myke explained, "Ah yes, I see the problem! This plant lacks essential nutrients found deep in the soil. But don't worry; we fungi can form special partnerships called mycorrhizae to share those resources."

Together, Fendrix, Floozit, and Myke worked hard to connect the roots of the struggling plant to Myke's network. Soon enough, the plant stood taller than ever before!

As they admired their work, Myke added, "You know, Fendrix and Floozit, there's another amazing relationship we fungi create  with algae or cyanobacteria forming something called lichens. We provide protection while sharing water and minerals, and they give us energy through photosynthesis."

With excitement, Fendrix exclaimed, "Wow! So many wonders exist between different kinds of living beings! It shows how interconnected we truly are."

But then, suddenly, dark clouds rolled over the forest, casting shadows on their newfound friendship. A storm was coming, threatening the delicate balance created by these remarkable partners. And so began an unexpected challenge for little Fendrix, Floozit, and Myke, teaching everyone that even when things get tough, the bonds formed by cooperation can still thrive against adversity.

Story about a Story:
Little Alice was known throughout her neighborhood for her unique appetite. She loved broccoli more than anything else! But she wouldn't go near any kind of meat, which made some people curious. They would often ask her mom, "Why doesn't Alice eat meat?" Her mother would smile patiently and say, "Alice has her own food preferences, and that's perfectly okay."

One sunny afternoon, Alice and her mom visited the local library. There, they found a book titled 'Tiny Tummies: Understanding Your Toddler's Eating Habits.' As they read together, Alice learned that her taste buds were still growing and developing new likes and dislikes every day. This discovery led to another question - "Mommy, how do our taste buds work?" With excitement in her eyes, Mom explained that taste buds tell us whether something tastes sweet, sour, bitter, or salty. Fascinated by all these facts, Alice felt even prouder of herself for knowing what she liked best.

As days passed, Alice tried various foods suggested by her mom and sometimes even enjoyed them too. However, despite trying hard, she never managed to appreciate the taste of meat. Eventually, the neighbors stopped asking questions when they saw Alice happily munching on her beloved broccoli and colorful array of other veggies.

Then came the annual summer picnic event organized by the community. All the kids played games, ran around, and eagerly waited for lunchtime. Platters filled with sandwiches, fruits, and  oh no, MEATBALLS! Seeing those round brown balls on everyone's plate, Alice couldn't help but feel left out. Quietly observing her friends enjoying their meal, she wondered if she had missed out on something delicious. Suddenly, she realized that understanding her taste buds didn't mean missing out on social experiences; instead, it helped her embrace who she was. And so, Alice continued relishing her green delights with joy, teaching everyone a valuable lesson about self-acceptance and exploration.

Story about a Story:
Once upon a time, in a small town in the United States, lived two best friends named Jamal and Lily. They were both nine years old and went to the same school. However, they noticed something strange - even though their classroom had separate seats for everyone, the kids who looked like Jamal had to sit in the back while those who looked like Lily got to sit in the front.

One day, Jamal asked his teacher, "Why can't I sit in the front row?" His teacher explained that it was because of the rules set by the school district long ago, during a time when people didn't understand much about fairness and equal treatment.

Jamal then shared this with Lily, who couldn't believe that her friend wasn't allowed to sit where he wanted. Together, they decided to do something about it. With help from their parents, they started learning more about the history of the African American civil rights movement in the mid-20th century. They discovered how brave men and women fought against unfair laws and practices so that all people could enjoy equal rights under the law.

They found out about Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Rosa Parks, Malcolm X, and many others who stood up for justice and freedom. These heroes used peaceful protests, speeches, and marches to bring attention to the unequal treatment faced by black Americans. Through these efforts, landmark legislation like the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Voting Rights Act of 1965 came into being.

Inspired by these stories, Jamal and Lily organized their classmates to stage a protest at school. Their goal was to challenge the seating arrangement rule and promote fairness for everyone. When the news reached the principal, she agreed to review the policy and soon announced new guidelines ensuring equitable seat allocation regardless of skin color.

However, not everything turned out as happily ever after as they thought. Even though the rule changed at their school, they learned that similar problems persisted across different towns and states. But now they knew better. They understood the importance of standing up for what's right, no matter how difficult the journey might seem. And most importantly, they realized that change starts with one voice speaking out against inequality  just like their own.

Story about a Story:
In a bustling city lived two best friends, Tino and Lulu. They were both curious learners who loved exploring the world around them. One day, they heard some big news - the labor union in their country had threatened to blockade the border to protest against the actions of a neighboring country's president! This got Tino and Lulu thinking about how different countries interact with each other.

Tino asked, "Lulu, what does 'blockading' mean?" Lulu replied, "Well, imagine if someone sets up a roadblock so no cars or trucks can pass through. A blockade is similar, but instead of blocking a road, it stops all trade between countries."

Curious, Tino wondered aloud, "Why would our labor union do something like that?" That's when their teacher, Ms. Naledi, overheard them talking and joined the conversation. She explained, "When people feel strongly about something, they might take bold steps to make sure their message gets across. In this case, the labor union believes that what happened wasn't fair, so they want to put pressure on the other country to change its ways."

As Tino and Lulu continued discussing the issue, they learned more about the role of governments and citizens in shaping relationships between nations. However, things didn't turn out exactly as they expected. While the debate brought attention to the matter, the conflict remained unsolved, teaching them a valuable lesson about complexities in real life. Sometimes, even when we try hard to create positive changes, issues may persist due to various factors beyond our control. Nonetheless, understanding these challenges helps us grow wiser and encourages us to keep learning and striving towards better solutions.

Suddenly, while still pondering the situation, Lulu looked up into the sky and exclaimed, "Look, Tino! Why is the sky blue today?" Ms. Naledi smiled and answered, "That's another fascinating topic related to light scattering called Rayleigh Scattering!" And thus, their discussion took yet another intriguing scientific detour, emphasizing the beauty of discovery and exploration, regardless of unexpected twists along the way.

Story about a Story:
Once upon a time, in a small town called Serenity Springs, lived two best friends named Max and Lily. They loved exploring nature and learning new things together. One day, they decided to learn about mindfulness and gratitude meditation from their wise friend, Dr. Oakley, the town's scientist.

Dr. Oakley greeted them warmly and said, "Mindfulness and gratitude meditation can help us feel happier, healthier, and more connected to our world. Let me teach you some techniques." She handed them each a colorful mat and asked them to find a comfortable spot under a big tree.

"First," she began, "focus on your breath. Deep breaths bring oxygen into your lungs, which then travels to your bloodstream and helps every cell in your body function better! Now close your eyes, breathe deeply, and notice how wonderful it feels."

Max and Lily followed her instructions, taking long, slow breaths, feeling refreshed by the cool breeze. Then, Dr. Oakley continued, "Next, use your senses to connect with your surroundings. See the beautiful blue sky, hear the rustling leaves, smell the flowers blooming nearby. By doing so, you'll become aware of the interconnectedness between yourself and the environment, realizing we're part of something much bigger!"

As they opened their eyes and looked around, they discovered an injured bird nearby. With kind hearts, they applied their newly learned skills; focusing on their breath and observing the creature carefully without judgement. Together, they nurtured its broken wing back to health.

Finally, Dr. Oakley reminded them, "Stay present and positive during your practice. It's easy to get lost in thoughts about yesterday or tomorrow, but being mindful means cherishing the current moments. And when expressing gratitude, remember the power of appreciation  it fosters happiness not only for ourselves but also spreads joy throughout the community!"

Feeling grateful, Max and Lily returned home, excited to share these lessons with others. However, tragedy struck the very next morning - wildfire ravaged Serenity Springs! Despite losing most possessions, Max and Lily remained hopeful, recalling the importance of staying present amidst adversities. In time, they helped rebuild their loving community stronger than ever before, spreading awareness about the value of mindfulness and gratitude along the way.

Story about a Story:
In the year 1789, a curious little girl named Eliza lived in England. She loved learning new things and asking questions about the world around her. One sunny day, she asked her wise old friend, Mr. Thompson, "Who sat on the English throne in my birth year?"

Mr. Thompson smiled and said, "King George III, dear Eliza." He then continued, "Did you know he was quite a remarkable king? His reign saw many important scientific advancements!"

Curious Eliza questioned, "What do you mean, Mr. Thompson?" With twinkling eyes, he began to tell her about two fascinating phenomena - light absorption and reflection.

"You see, Eliza," explained Mr. Thompson, "When white sunlight reaches our atmosphere, it gets scattered, or redirected, by tiny particles. Blue light has shorter waves and scatters more easily than other colors, making our skies appear blue!"

Eliza gasped, wide-eyed. "And what does this have to do with King George III, sir?"

Mr. Thompson chuckled, "Well, Eliza, during his rule, scientists were intrigued by these natural occurrences! They studied how objects absorb certain wavelengths while reflecting others; thus creating different colors we observe. These studies led to better understanding color theory and even improvements in dye production!"

As days passed, Eliza couldn't stop thinking about their discussion. Then came the shocking news: despite victories earlier in his reign, King George III faced great adversity when America declared independence. An unexpected twist indeed, teaching Eliza that sometimes outcomes aren't always as desired, much like how only some colors bounce off surfaces while others get absorbed. Just as light behaves according to specific rules, so too must nations adapt to changes brought forth by progress and innovation.

Story about a Story:
In a bustling city full of towering buildings and whizzing cars, lived two best friends named Alex and Taylor. They were both curious and loved learning about the world around them. One day, they discovered a mysterious book filled with unreadable symbols and codes. Excited by their discovery, they decided to explore its contents further.

Alex said, "Wow! I wonder what these strange symbols mean?"
Taylor replied, "I think they might be unstructured data - information without a predefined format."
"But how do we make sense of all this?" asked Alex.
Taylor smiled and answered, "We can use a tool called TEXT\_ANALYSIS\_EXTRACT in our friend SAP Hana!"

They soon realized that before using the magical TEXT\_ANALYSIS\_EXTRACT spell, they would first need to install the Predictive Analytics Library (PAL). After gathering the necessary ingredients, or rather downloading the required software packages, they prepared themselves to unlock the secrets hidden within the mystical pages.

With excitement, they opened up SAP Hana Studio and connected to their SAP system. A new adventure began when they launched the SQL console to prepare the incantation. Together, they chanted:

"SELECT * FROM TABLE(TEXT\_ANALYSIS\_EXTRACT('ENGLISH', :INPUT_DATA,'TOKENIZATION'));"

As they watched the results unfold, colorful tokens appeared, representing each word found in the text. Their eyes widened as they saw the magic come alive, transforming meaningless strings into structured insights.

However, despite successfully deciphering some parts of the codex, they quickly learned that understanding complex texts requires more than just tokenizing individual words. With many challenges ahead, the two friends understood that knowledge comes gradually and sometimes accompanied by unexpected twists. Nevertheless, driven by curiosity and armed with scientific tools, every obstacle became an opportunity for growth and exploration.

Professor Phoneme explained, "German has a special way of making sounds, unlike any other Germanic languages! For instance, there's the '' sound like in brtchen (bread). It looks like two dots above the u, and it feels like kissing the air!"

Eddie, Duchess, and Swede tried to make the sound but struggled. Germy grinned, saying, "It might seem tricky now, but keep practicing! You'll get the hang of it."

As they continued exploring, they realized that although German had unique sounds, many others resembled those in Dutch and Swedish. However, Germy pointed out something peculiar - the infamous "ch" sound, which was quite challenging even for native Germans!

Intrigued by these differences, they practiced each other's languages until sunset when suddenly, a storm approached! Scared, they looked around for shelter, only finding one tree sturdy enough  under Germy's long neck!

Huddled together, they learned that despite having various sounds, every language helped them communicate with one another. And sometimes, understanding didn't require perfection; instead, it came from accepting our uniqueness and appreciating the journey towards knowing more.

So, though Eddie, Duchess, Swede, and Germy couldn't fully grasp each other's tongue twisters, they cherished the unforgettable experience of trying. After all, the real treasure lay in embracing diversity and celebrating the beauty of contrasting sound systems.

Story about a Story:

"Wow, look at that!" said Sam, pointing towards the sky. "What do you think it's doing here?"

Alex replied excitedly, "Maybe it's here to help us take care of our plants! Let's go ask Farmer Joe."

Farmer Joe explained, "This drone is special because it can fly around our fields and check on all the crops without us having to walk everywhere. See those green parts? That's a camera that takes pictures of the plants. And when we get these photos, we can see if any part of our field needs more water or if some plants aren't growing so well."

Sam asked, "So, it helps us know what's wrong before it becomes a big problem?"

"Exactly!" nodded Farmer Joe. "Just like checking your temperature when you feel sick, this lets us catch problems early and make sure our plants stay healthy."

As days passed, the duo saw many benefits of using drones. Not only did it monitor crop health, but also helped in managing water better by detecting which areas needed more water and less. Moreover, when tiny bugs started appearing on some plants, the drone quickly spotted them too. This allowed Farmer Joe to treat only affected areas instead of spraying chemicals all over unnecessarily.

One fine evening after dinner, while discussing their day, Sam suddenly looked worried. He turned to Alex and asked, "But what happens if something goes wrong with the drone? What will happen to our crops then?"

And just as he finished speaking, the drone whirred softly before falling silently onto the ground. Their worst fear had come true! All three stared at each other nervously, realizing that although technology brought numerous advantages, sometimes even machines fail, teaching them an important lesson about depending too much on tools and remembering to keep learning traditional ways alongside technological advancements.

Story about a Story:
